channel.title: News & Updates on Pandaqi Blog
channel.description: Recent content in News & Updates on Pandaqi Blog

item.title: My Online Store Has Launched!
item.description: What a miracle! Great times are upon us! After working on this project for exactly one year, I have launched my online store. A large international store, selling everything I ever made and probably everything I will make, which obviously includes the many board games and video games I design.

item.title: Pandaqi Games: Version 4.0?
item.description: The past few years I’ve written several articles about updating the Pandaqi website. They alternated between updating the code behind it all, and updating the design/look of the website.

item.title: How I Coded My Own Webshop
item.description: This article explains the steps I took to build my own “custom” webshop. It took a lot of effort to figure out how to set it up, how to connect different systems to each other, how to prevent making a lot of silly (or even costly) mistakes. That’s why I wrote about the entire process and hope others can learn from it!

item.title: The Big Fat Website Update of 2025
item.description: The past few years, I’ve created a handful of large websites (my game studio, my author website, my portfolio, etcetera). For the most part, after creating many websites while I was still in high school/university, I knew what I was doing. Most of these websites were well-designed from the start, which is great!

item.title: The Principle of Least Maintenance
item.description: If you’ve followed this blog for some time, or have simply encountered a few of my update articles, you know that I lost of a lot of time maintaining Pandaqi. Not adding new content. Not redesigning to make it look more flashy. Simply maintaining: fixing old bugs, making things a little faster, moving old games to a better system I developed for the newer ones.

item.title: Pandaqi Games: 2025 Update II
item.description: This article explains the second major update I implemented for my Pandaqi Games website. (I usually end up having multiple such articles per year, as I slowly fix bugs, make the website more user friendly, etcetera.)

item.title: Announcement: (Dutch) Webshop Launched
item.description: This article is a quick “announcement” that I launched my own webshop. I’ll keep it short, as the online store contains mostly Dutch merchandise and isn’t very tightly related to games. (Which is what this website and this blog is all about.)

item.title: Pandaqi Games: 2025 Update I
item.description: This article explains the first major update I implemented for my Pandaqi Games website. (I usually end up having multiple such articles per year, as I slowly fix bugs, make the website more user friendly, etcetera.)

item.title: Let's Talk About: Throneless Games
item.description: This article is a short explanation of the Throneless Games, but mostly a personal reflection on what their creation and process means to me. I wrote it because it was interesting to realize and perhaps helps other creatives keep good habits and motivation. I also wrote it to have a nice devlog article to link to from the Throneless Games main page ;)

item.title: Pandaqi Games: 2024 Update IV
item.description: This is my final update to the Pandaqi website and all its tools/systems/design for the year 2024. (At least, that’s the plan. I always end up finding more things I want to fix, but I’ll push those to my next big website update in 2025.)

item.title: The Dangers of Desynchronized
item.description: Not too long ago, I made a very simple party game called Slippery Slopes. I made it rather quickly in a single weekend, but it turned out okay.

item.title: My Return to Game Dev
item.description: Once in a while I get an email from someone who enjoyed a game of mine. They usually don’t lead with that, no, they tell me about a bug, or ask a question, or offer “game services” I might want. But if I engage with them, then the truth is usually revealed after one or two emails: they discovered me one day, played a few of my multiplayer games with friends or their kids, had a great time, thus decided to email me.

item.title: No More Play Store
item.description: This is just a quick announcement that I will never be putting games on the Play Store / App Store again.

item.title: The Big Simplification Update (of 2024)
item.description: In this article I want to explain some pretty major changes I made to the Pandaqi website. What, why, how, and other questions containing the letter “w”.

item.title: Pandaqi Games: 2024 Update III
item.description: This article explains the reason behind another big update to my game studio website. One that is still in progress and probably will be for a while.

item.title: Pandaqi Games: 2024 Update II
item.description: This update to the Pandaqi Games website is much smaller than usual, but still very important. That’s why I wanted to write a short article about the problem, the changes and why I made them.

item.title: Git and the Horror of Newlines
item.description: A few days ago, I got the scare of my life. I had just pushed a huge update to the Pandaqi website, but when I checked it out … almost all the images and fonts were broken. No, even worse, corrupted.

item.title: Pandaqi Games: 2024 Update
item.description: Here we are again. Another big update to my game studio website that is almost entirely behind the scenes. This means all my work won’t be immediately visible to others, which is why I write articles like these to explain what I did (and feel good about being productive).

item.title: My Journey to Becoming a Game Designer
item.description: The original title for this article was “nobody becomes anything overnight”. While true, I was afraid this would set the wrong tone or give the wrong impression. Because this article merely showcases my journey to becoming a game designer.

item.title: Pandaqi Games: Solving the Nightmare called Text
item.description: My game studio website has become so large and interactive these past few years that I basically have to do a big rewrite behind the scenes every few months now.

item.title: Why all my games were removed from the Play Store
item.description: For many years now, I’ve had about 10 games on the Play Store. All those games were also released on desktop, but their primary target was usually mobile (free and supported by ads).

item.title: Pandaqi Games: The Big Typescript Update
item.description: If you thought we were done with huge updates to Pandaqi Games for this year—as did I—then you were wrong.

item.title: Pandaqi Games: 2023 Update (III)
item.description:
Over the year, I’ve published a few updates on this blog about the inner workings of Pandaqi Games.

First, I explained how the code was a HUGE mess (from almost 10 years of projects, going back to when I was a kid and had no clue what good programming was). I solved that by moving everything into simple libraries that were reused across the whole website.

item.title: Pandaqi Games: 2023 Update (II)
item.description: A few months ago, I already wrote an article about a huge update to Pandaqi games. Behind the scenes, lots of code was removed and improved, leading to the creation of a few “tools” that handle everything for all pages.

item.title: PQ_DAW: A music editor for the web
item.description: PQ_DAW ( = Pandaqi DAW) is a small, limited web implementation of a “Digital Audio Workstation”. It uses vanilla website code (HTML, CSS, JavaScript) and was designed to plug into the Hugo static website generator.

item.title: PQ_WORDS: A dictionary for games
item.description: I made a thing! One that others might like as well: a library of word lists. Use them for word games. Use them to quickly prototype new ideas or generate random words / concepts for inspiration. Use them for a spelling contest. Use them however you like!

item.title: Bamboo Documentation
item.description: Bamboo was made to introduce people to programming. It has a limited set of features and terrible performance (if you want to do anything serious with it).

item.title: Bamboo: my own coding language
item.description: Bamboo is my own lightweight scripting language. This article is about the whole process of creation, from start to finish. If you want to use it, read the documentation.

item.title: To modern rulebooks and beyond!
item.description: The past few months, I’ve made some huge updates to this website and my (board) games on it. (Check out the other articles, like this one)

item.title: Pandaqi Games: 2023 Update
item.description: The past few months, I’ve updated all my websites in significant ways. Pandaqi Games was the main focal point. In this article, I’ll explain why I made changes and what I changed exactly.

item.title: PQ_MIDI: A music player for interactive tutorials
item.description: I made a thing again! Something I couldn’t find anywhere else on the internet, but which proved to be immensely useful. It’s called “PQ_MIDI” ( = Pandaqi Midi).

item.title: Pandaqi Tutorials has been redesigned!
item.description: The name Pandaqi actually comes from this tutorial website. It was the first serious website I launched. I worked on it for months before launch, then for at least 6 months afterwards to perfect it. In that period, I probably wrote and designed the best tutorials I’ll ever write :p

item.title: The blog has been redesigned!
item.description: Long ago, when I started my Pandaqi Blog, I wanted to try a new CMS and chose Grav.

item.title: One Paper Games: 2022 Update
item.description: Two years ago now, I started creating something I called “One Paper Games”. I created a handful of them, experimenting with all sorts of fun ways to play games, and am very proud of the results.

item.title: How I redesigned my Game Studio website
item.description:
I’ve been making games and uploading them (under the moniker “Pandaqi”) for about 7+ years now.

At first, they were just a few hobby projects on some sketchy website.

item.title: Print and Play Games!
item.description:
It’s finally here!

I have completed and uploaded my official page full of free boardgames: Print & Play Boardgames
